ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend this course to any student interested in Baroque italian art. If you are interested in the development of that style (who isn't?) then I absolutely recommend this course. I would say that some experience in art history would be helpful, but not necessarily required for success.
Easy class for non-majors looking to take a lecture beyond the intro surveys. Low workload and good lectures.

An overview of baroque art in rome. The first half if about painting, then second half about sculpture and architecture. I personally liked the first half better, but overall it was an interesting course to take if you have previous interest in the area.

This is a truly incredible course on Baroque Rome. Professor Suthor is a wonderful instructor and person! The class is divided into three sections--the first on painting, the second on sculpture (Bernini!) and the third on architecture. All of the art is wonderful, and the texts are fascinating! And, we took a field trip to the Metropolitan Museum with Professor Suthor to discuss many of the paintings we'd seen in the course, which was a blast. There was a weekly discussion section, but it was optional as it was impossible to find a time all students could attend. If you like Rome and Bernini and Caravaggio, TAKE THIS COURSE!
This is a fabulous course to take if you want a lighter art history course. It's a rarely studied period of art and you learn so much.

Take this course. Geared towards art history majors--a fairly high level of discourse. A fantastic introduction to the Baroque period in Rome, approx. 1590-1660. Profesor Suthor is unlike any other, a true expert. Light readings, about 20 pages of criticism for every lecture. You need to do them, though, as sections revolve around their ideas.
Challenging and stimulating introduction to baroque art
